herein lies the flaw in the abortionist (if thats a word) argument. "abortionists" say its OK to kill the fetus because it can't feel/think. of course in reality fetuses do feel and think. at less than 12 weeks a fetus has a fully functioning brain, beating heart and moving limbs.

 
 
 Claim:
 The 12-week fetus experiences pain. 
 
 Facts:
 At this stage of the pregnancy, the brain and nervous system are still in a very early stage of development. The beginnings of the brain stem, which includes a rudimentary thalamus and spinal cord, is being formed. Most brain cells are not developed. Without a cerebral cortex (gray matter covering the brain), pain impulses cannot be received or perceived. Additionally, experts find that newborns at 26-27 weeks' gestation (24-25 weeks' fetal age) who survive have significantly less response to pain than do full term newborns. 
 
 The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
 Statement on Pain of the Fetus
 
 We know of no legitimate scientific information that supports the statement that a fetus experiences pain early in pregnancy. 
 
 We do know that the cerebellum attains its final configuration in the seventh month and that mylenization (or covering) of the spinal cord and the brain begins between the 20th and 40th weeks of pregnancy. These, as well as other neurological developments, would have to be in place for the fetus to receive pain.
 
 To feel pain, a fetus needs neurotransmitted hormones. In animals, these complex chemicals develop in the last third of gestation. We know of no evidence that humans are different. 
 
 Claim:
 The 12-week fetus makes purposeful movements (e.g., agitated movement in an attempt to avoid suction cannula). 
 
 Facts:
 At this stage of pregnancy, all fetal movement is reflexive in nature rather than purposeful, since the latter requires cognition, which is the ability to perceive and know. For cognition to occur, the cortex (gray matter covering the brain) must be present, as well as myelinization (covering sheath) of the spinal cord and attached nerves, which is not the case. 
 
 An example of the reflex withdrawal without pain occurs in an anencephalic (absent brain) newborn. Another known example of the reflex movement at this stage of human pregnancy is thumb sucking in utero.
 
 What is termed "frantic activity" by the fetus is a reflex response of the fetus resulting from movement of the uterus and its contents induced by operator manipulation of the suction curette or the ultrasound transducer on the abdomen. This same type of response would likely occur with any external stimulus. A one-cell organism such as an amoeba will reflexively move or display a withdrawal reaction when touched.

I just wanted to say something, and I don't know whether this really deals with this particular thread on abortion, but... please hear me out... I don't want to start any kind of a 'fight', I just want to say some things and I hope that something like this is considered in the debates.
 I am 4 months pregnant, and I just found out this week that there are a lot (9) very serious problems with the baby. None of these things can ever be medically corrected, and the baby is dying. It is considered to be a non-viable pregnancy, meaning that the baby can not survive. Because there are specific defects in the heart and brain, it can only live for a few more months, the chance that it will make it to a full 9 months are 1% and the chance that it will live after being born are basically zero. That being said, I have seen 3 specialists and have heard the same results, and I have to have the pregnancy terminated. This is not something that I really chose to do, I do have the choice not to do it and let the pregnancy continue, but as I said the baby is dying and the longer I let it go the worse things are going to get, and I would be putting my own life in danger. I am not necessarily pro-choice, I have never really got into either side of that debate, and I haven't really condemmed someone for doing that, but I knew it was something I couldn't do myself. This is a very hard thing for me, and I never pictured myself in this situation, I never even imagined I would ever have to make a choice like that, but I do have to make that choice. The baby is going to die, I don't want it to suffer any longer and I can't put my own life at risk because I have a daughter already that needs me. So, as hard as it is to actually type that and to say it to people that I don't know, I just wanted that to be said so that maybe things like this can be considered in these debates. As I said, I'm not really for or against anything, I hadn't ever had to really deal with it so I kind of stayed out of it, but now that this has happened I can say that I feel a little angry that people do it 'just because'.. I hope that no one that reads this ever HAS to make that choice, and I hope that anyone who reads it who decides to make that choice for their own personal (not medical) reasons really takes into consideration what they are doing... it's not easy, and there are people I know who know my situation and are still making judgement, but I wish that they would realize that this isn't something that I want, and I never wanted it to have to happen.
 Please consider all that, and thanks for reading this.

 Thank you for your question, and I don't mind you asking. I've found that it's a little easier to make sense of some of it when you talk about it.
 And you're right, situations like that are rare, but in this situation that is basically the case, at least so I have been told. I've been to 2 maternal-fetal specialists and 2 genetic specialists, and we have consulted with doctors at the National Institute of Health and everything has been the same. That being said, I will tell a little of what we are dealing with.. at this point, they have found 8 specific things wrong, and some of these things on their own aren't so bad, but they are more severe than normal, and combined with the other things are life threatening to the baby. The baby has cystic hygroma, which is a tumor that is filled with lymph fluid, and that same fluid is also on the head so that it is 2 times the normal size. They can't do anything to get the fluid out, and the only thing that could be done with the tumor is to remove it and they just have no way to do that. It has hypoplastic left heart, which is basically underdevelopment of the left side of the heart, but in this case it's not there at all. This eventually causes heart failure because right side of the heart is doing the job of the right and left sides alone, and the heart has already started to fail. The lungs are seriously underdeveloped, I think they said that they are developed to the point of what they would be at 2 months, but they have stopped and won't develop anymore, and they won't be able to function at all. Another thing is called omphalocele, and that basically means that the baby's intestines are outside of the body and protruding into the umbilical cord and not inside the body where they should be. There is a mass on the umbilical cord itself, which can rupture at any time, which is what would put my life at risk, since I wouldn't have an immediate knowledge that it had done that. There are other problems with the umbilical cord, and it is missing things that need to be there to get nutrients to the baby. Some of these things can be medically corrected later on if they weren't so severe, but they have told me that there is no way to correct any of it, just because of how bad they are. I have to see another geneticist to have more tests done so they can determine why all of this happened, because this many severe anomalities is very very rare, and they aren't sure yet what caused it, but they think it is a chromosal thing. 
 And you're right also in saying that a lot of women would put their own life at risk to save their child's, but the baby is dying and they can't save it. The prognosis of survival is maybe two more months at the most, the chance of survival to the full 9 months is less than 1% and if it made it that far the chance of survival after birth is less than zero. I have probably driven my doctors crazy with all the phone calls and questions, but the answers have all been the same, and I can wait it out and let it go on its own, but they say that medically that isn't the right choice. Morally speaking, I do feel the best choice is to wait it out. I know that the baby is dying, and there is nothing I can do to change that, and nothing any doctor can change, but the more advanced the pregnancy gets the more complications there are, and I can't put my own life in danger knowing these facts. That's not a selfish decision that I made for myself, I made that decision because I have a little girl that needs me and I don't want to take the chance of making her grow up without her mother. A lot of the decisions I'm making are being based on that. If I knew there was ANY remote chance for this baby, there wouldn't be a decision at all, but I can't change the facts, and I know exactly what is going on and what the outcome is going to be.
 But I do thank you for reading my post and for your questions.. I hope this helps a little....

 Well, first of all, I think you misunderstood me. I don't believe it is right for a woman to have an abortion because she finds out that her baby is going to be handicapped. If the doctors had told me that, I would have the baby, no question. If I knew that the baby had any chance of survival, I would have it... but any risk to me aside, the baby is dying, and isn't going to make it long enough to even be born. I wish they had only told me that it could be born with a physical and/or mental disability, but it isn't. If that were all that were wrong, but I still knew I was at risk, I would probably take that chance then... but I can't truly say what I would do because I wasn't faced with that.. if the baby had chance to live, I would be looking at things a lot differently than I am. The doctors have told me the severity of the defects and the combination of them is lethal, and the baby stopped developing at between 2 and 3 months.. I am 4 months now. My doctor told me it is very rare to have this many defects present all at once, and they are a lot more severe than normal, which is also very rare, which is why she sent me to several specialists and geneticists. They don't know yet why it happened, but I have had tests done so hopefully I will have some kind of answers soon. I told my doctors that, knowing the baby is already dying, I feel the best thing for me to do is to let it 'go' on its own.. they said that was my choice, but they strongly advised against it.. one doctor flat out said not to do it.. I don't think they would have recommended a termination if they thought there was any type of chance. So all I can do is look at my options, and weigh them, and try to figure out what is the best choice for everyone involved.. it may not be the 'right' choice, but no matter what I do I will always wonder if I did the right thing. I can either go against the doctors, and carry out the pregnancy for as long as the baby lives, even knowing that the baby is dying, and that as it progresses the problems get worse and eventually will put my own life in danger, and if something goes wrong I die with the baby, not instead of it, or I can terminate it now before things get worse and continue to be a mother to my daughter and one day have another child and pray that things won't be like this again. No matter which choice I make, the baby is going to die, and I can't save it and neither can any doctor.
 But no, under normal circumstances I don't think it's right... just because I am going through this doesn't mean I think it's right.. unfortunately I have had a few friends who have had them as a sort of 'birth control', and I was so disappointed in them, but I figured it was their own choice... I just knew it was not the choice for me. Even now, I don't believe it's the right choice, but I'm thinking of my daughter in this.... if I didn't have her I probably wouldn't really give a damn if I lived or died...
 
 I also wanted to say that I didn't post any of that on here to try to change anyone's mind about what they believe is right or wrong, and I know it technically probably doesn't qualify as a 'debate'.  I did get my amniocentesis tests back, so they now have a 'name' for what is wrong. It's called trisomy 18 syndrome, and it happens when one parent passes along 2 chromosomes, when each parent is supposed to only pass one. So they say that there are 3 copies of chromosome 18 present in each metaphase cell, and all they can tell me is that it is something that just 'happens', but now that they know exactly what is wrong, I have to go to another genetic specialist and have tests done again... I don't know if they will be able to tell me which one of us passed the extra chromosome, or why, but if they can tell me I would like to know. Down's syndrome is trisomy 21 sydrome, so I think it is the same type of thing, only this sydrome is fatal.. they said that typically 90% of the time the fetus will miscarry on its own, and then the 10% that make after that have a 95% chance of stillbirth, while the other 5% won't make it to a year. So the odds aren't good at all, and in my case the problems are more severe than usual so I don't even have those chances. I knew that things were bad, but hearing the actual figures on everything makes me realize how bad they really are. I was told that the majority of the time, it is women who are in their 40s or older that have this happen, and I'm only 24, so now my chance of something like this happening again are 20%... the only good thing with that is now that the doctors know, if I get pregnant again they will immediately do tests to see if anything is wrong. The trisomy 18 syndrome isn't necessarily putting me at risk, but they had found some type of mass or tumor on the umbilical cord and they don't think it is related, but they are afraid that it is going to rupture. So far no one knows what it is.. at least they haven't told me.
 They did tell me that the baby's heart rate has slowed down significantly since last week, but my doctor is still telling me to have the termination asap and I don't understand why now, and no one is really giving me any answers anymore.

If you see the fetus as a human being, meaning that you hold the sentimental attachments humans have with each other, then yes it would be wrong. However, that's an awkward question for those of us who are pro-choice/pro-abortion. Some of us don't see the fetus as a human being, and see it as a fetus, so we would say no.

I have a question for all the "Pro-Choice" people out there? When DOES the fetus become a human? When does it become immoral to kill it? Conception, First Trimester, Second Tremester? Birth, one month, Two months? Where?

 
 It's different for everyone. In my opinion, the basic traits of a human that a fetus does not have are: self-awareness, the ability to communicate, consciousness, reasoning, and independent activity.

I think the technical term fetus applies all the way up to birth after it has stopped being an embryo. Pure terminology isn't going to help decide the issue as I tink the requirement for being a fetus is when it is recognisably human.
 
 A fetus is human, but it isn't the point, what matters is when it is a person. A human can not actually be detirmined scientifically, no species can as the entire concept is arteficial and doesn't really apply to the real world. Even by comparison, if you took a sample from an adult human, or a whole load of adult humans to make a standard, you wouldn't be able to tell the difference unless you were looking at specific genes between a fetus/embryo or a cancer cell (which is self sustaining, capable of replication and will have a different genentic code from its parent). You could distinguish both from a chimp or a mouse but the two would fit your genetic defintion of human.
 
 I would say it is wrong to abort once the central nervous sytem has become developed and the fetus is capable of concious thought. Makes perfect sense as the thing we prize in humans is the brain and it is this what we use to define individuals (otherwise amputation would be considered murder), until this point as far as the fetus is concerned there is no difference from it being aborted and it just existing.

 The debate is not if its ok to kill a human being because obviously your not going to get a huge debate on that but rather is the fetus a human being.

 
 Whether a fetus is a person is not something open to consideration. An apple is not an orange. The reason that we have two words to apply as labels is simply because they absolutely are not the same thing. It is that simple.
